@danny0405 had a good feedback - since ProjectMergeRule can also be used by HepPlanner, and in some cases user would use HepPlanner to merge physical project nodes at the end of optimization phase, so I update this change to only disable physical project merge under volcano planer.

Based on the discussion in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2970 this does not seem to be the desired approach to solve the problem. To avoid confusion, I am closing this PR, and if relevant we can reopen it in the future.

Have you seen https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2223 ?
I think 3455 duplicates 2223, and, unfortunately, there's no trivial solution for it.

To get this to build without warnings, I had to remove a call to `ClientCacheFactory.setPdxPersistent`; is is deprecated and apparently a no-op.

@tzolov You wrote this code; can you please comment?

@julianhyde I'll try to get this upgrade through

`ClientCacheFactory.setPdxPersistent` is not needed (on client cache)
Fixed by #1581

OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available. If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting `@dependabot ignore this major version` or `@dependabot ignore this minor version`.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.
Superseded by #1582.
Sure @zabetak ~
Thanks for review!
@asereda-gs can you take a look at this?

@julianhyde will do.
as a general approach should we create a JRIA ticket for this PR ?

I think these PRs from dependabot count as "small", therefore no JIRA is necessary. However, it is worth doing a build on each JDK version and generating javadoc. If a JIRA makes that easier, go ahead.

> Have you seen https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2223 ?
> I think 3455 duplicates 2223, and, unfortunately, there's no trivial solution for it.

I don't think this is a duplication. This patch tries to improve the optimization performance by avoid firing redundant rules. It's not particularly related to cycles between RelSubset.
Will close this PR. The progress now is in https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/1587.
This patch is a part of https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/1587 already.

>I was thinking that the update of the Website instructions

The major part of the current `mvn` instructions are related to "release".
I'm inclined to just add "below instructions are stale", and update the list to the proper ones right during the release.

For instance, we can copy&paste the instructions from Avatica release.

> You send a lot of useful information in the various mails and I think some parts from there definitely deserve to be on the Website.

That's my intention as well.

> I'm inclined to just add "below instructions are stale", and update the list to the proper ones right during the release.

Just curious why during the release and not together with this PR?

> Just curious why during the release and not together with this PR?

TL;DR: to save time.

I'm bad at predicting the future, so I suggest to just try the release, see which commands work, and which configuration options are required.
That is exactly the process we used to release Apache JMeter with pretty much the same Gradle build, and it worked.


Have you seen this: https://github.com/vlsi/vlsi-release-plugins/blob/master/plugins/stage-vote-release-plugin/README.md#making-a-release-candidate ?
In my opinion, it covers the two commands that are needed to publish the artifacts.
What if I just put a cross-reference?

On top of that, there's a section on "use of Docker" which, I guess, @F21 could help to fix (e.g. based on the findings from Avatica)
Or create a JIRA first to share some context about this change?
Yes, a JIRA case would be great. Its summary should describe the problem (preferably in terms that would make sense to and end user, such as a SQL statement).
Thanks for review.

I understand. I was thinking that if the next RM does not have much experience with the release process or Gradle not having any instructions to begin with may be frustrating. The cross-reference you mentioned may be enough to help people get started.

@XuQianJin-Stars I left a couple comments and I hope you don't mind, but I rewrote some of the documentation for grammar and clarity. I don't think this needs to be done in this PR, but it looks like for both `csv` and `json`, the `mapping` parameter for each column could be optionally eliminated. For `csv`, the default would be the position in the mapping array and for `json`, the default would be the `json` key.

> @XuQianJin-Stars I left a couple comments and I hope you don't mind, but I rewrote some of the documentation for grammar and clarity. I don't think this needs to be done in this PR, but it looks like for both `csv` and `json`, the `mapping` parameter for each column could be optionally eliminated. For `csv`, the default would be the position in the mapping array and for `json`, the default would be the `json` key.

There's https://stackoverflow.com/a/58618280/1261287 , so we could add the following (to the regular CI workflow)

```
- if: contains(github.event.head_commit.message, 'slow_test_please')
... testSlow
```

to enable running slow tests in case it is needed (e.g. in your case when you are altering the job config, and nobody is sure it would work without trying)

WDYT?

Adding a conditional job seems like a good idea! I will give it a try. 

Other than that there are ways to test that the new config works (e.g., https://github.com/zabetak/calcite/runs/315831584).

@julianhyde thanks for reviewing. Have tried to address your comments.

I made a change in last push that change `wstart` `wend` to `window_start` `window_end`. The purpose is to make added fields more readable.
Hive dialect support where? In the JDBC adapter or in the SQL parser? Change the JIRA description and the commit message to fully describe the change, even to someone who does not read the code.
Spelling: behavior  not beheavior

`ScalarFunctionImpl` determines NullPolicy based on annotations, while `TableFunctionImpl` sets `NullPolicy=ANY` by default for all cases.
However, according to the javadoc in `TableFunction`, `null` arguments are allowed.
```
  /**
   * Returns the row type of the table yielded by this function when
   * applied to given arguments. Only literal arguments are passed,
   * non-literal are replaced with default values (null, 0, false, etc).
   *
   * @param arguments arguments of a function call (only literal arguments
   *                  are passed, nulls for non-literal ones)
   * @return element type of the table (e.g. {@code Object[].class})
   */
  Type getElementType(List<Object> arguments);
```

Hi, @julianhyde,
Current now, I adopt the approach as that in `ScalarFunctionImpl` to dynamically determines the `NullPolicy` based on annotation.
But as shown in `TableFunctionTests`, it seems not to be reasonable when a table function returns `null`. The code generated (`org.apache.calcite.runtime.Enumerables.slice0(null)`) will produce NPE.

Comparing with `nestedLoopJoinAsList`, `nestedLoopJoinOptimized` saves effort to cache inner values and result by replaying inner values. Its' more memory efficient ~

R: @vladimirdolzhenko

Actually seems like this change will make `:ubenmark:jmh` be triggered by `./gradlew check`. Is the original structure intentional to avoid benmarks run by `check`?

If it is intentional, is there a separate command to run benchmarks? 
If it is not intentional, do we want to avoid benchmarks run by `check`?
